history.content:
ee120 is a hard prereq btw. idk if it's changed but if you ask please let us know.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

1) I believe it is as difficult as EECS 126 with less workload, only homework no labs.

2) For me personally it helped a lot, and it turned out to be an important component of my research,
which is about stochastic processes and learning theory.
It is an intuitive/engineering course in stochastic processes,
taught by Professor Anantharam who is one of the most prominent mathematicians that we have in the EECS department.
STAT 205A/B also cover the syllabus of EE 226A, but are more theoretical, and heavy on analysis. They are more advanced than EE 226A.

STAT 210A is a good option too, though it's not the same syllabus as EE 226A, they only have a small intersection.


3) Nothing to do with computer vision.
Machine learning is broad term, eg the Kalman filter is machine learning for me, so yeah EE 226A has to do with machine learning.

4) probably you just enroll, there are always enough spots.
ee120 is a hard prereq btw. idk if it's changed but if you ask please let us know.

children.subject:
Emailing professors for such questions is a bad idea.

They receive thousand of emails, and those are type of questions that should be asked in person during/after the first class.
I just emailed him, and he replied with a polite and helpful response inquiring more of my background. Will update with more details

From prof Anantharam:
Thanks. I would not advise taking EE 226A without having taken EE 120 beforehand. 
However, given the strength of your record so far, you could give it a shot to take EE 120
concurrently, if you are willing to be at some disadvantage with respect to the others in the
course in terms of preparation.
The material that uses EE 120 more intensively appears in the latter half of the course. 
We do use Fourier transforms throughout the course in material related to characteristic
functions etc.
Thank you! To the anon who asked about 120 being a hard prereq, I'm in 120 right now so that shouldn't be an issue for me. I would go ahead and email Professor Anantharam if you haven't taken it.

history.content:
Hi I took 126 last semester and found it really interesting, and I want to take 226A next semester (Fa '19). I have a few questions about the class:

1) How difficult/time-consuming will the class be? I plan on taking it with 189 and 106A, would this be an okay course load?

2) For those who have taken 226A, how interesting was the class and how much did you feel like it helped you further develop your understanding of probability theory and random processes? If you didn't like this class in particular, are there any alternatives taught in the math/stats departments that you would recommend?

3) As of now, I'm planning on working in industry in the ML/Computer Vision area after graduating. Given this, how much would I personally get out of 226A?

4) I haven't taken any graduate-level classes yet, how exactly would I go about enrolling in these? Would I just email the professor(s) teaching the class saying that I'm interested? If there has been a past piazza post about this, please link it below, I can't seem to find anything regarding this topic. 

Thanks in advance!
history.subject: EE 226A
